module.p: do (in)to, for is the (leniting) illative preposition.

section.p:
The default form of the illative preposition is simply do –
do thaigh into a house
do Nirribhidh into Norway
do thrì làithean into three days

Before a word beginning with a vowel or fh-, do is reduplicated to do dh’ –
do dh’aislingean into dreams
do dh’Èirinn into Ireland
do dh’ochd rionnagan into eight stars
Note that do is often spelled as (unlenited) do, especially in older texts. In both speech and writing, it is often reduced to just a.

When the immediately following word is a singular form of the definite article, the linking form don (in older usage don) is used –
don an taigh into the house
don a’ bhaile into the town But –
do na h-aislingean into the dreams, rather than do na h-aislingean
Note that don an and don a’ often reduce to just don – don taigh, don bhaile.

Fused forms are sometimes used when the immediately following word is a possessive determiner –
do mo thaigh into my house ≈ dham thaigh (previously, dom thaigh)
do do thaigh into your house ≈ dhad thaigh (previously, dod thaigh)
do a h-òran into her song ≈ dha h-òran (previously do h-òran)
do a chraoibh into his tree ≈ dha chraoibh (previously do chraoibh)
do ar n-achadh into our field ≈ dhar n-achadh (previously dar n-achadh)
do bhur leapannan into your beds ≈ dhur leapannan (previously dur leapannan)
do an taighean to their houses ≈ dhan taighean (previously dan taighean)
do am baile to their town ≈ dham baile (previously dam baile)

Conjugated prepositions are used in place of do mi, do thu, ... , do iad –
dhomh into me
dhut into you
dhi into her/it
dha into him/it
dhuinn into us
dhuibh into you
dhaibh into them

There are also emphatic forms (cf. do mise, do thusa, ... , do iadsan) –
dhòmhsa into me
dhutsa into you
dhìse into her/it
dhàsan into him/it
dhuinne into us
dhuibhse into you
dhaibhsan into them
Note that the form dhaibhsan breaks the ‘slender-to-slender, broad-to-broad’ spelling rule, and hence is sometimes found written with a hyphen – dhaibh-san.

Finally, there are also reflexive forms (cf. do mi fhìn, do thu fhèin, ... , do iad fhèin) –
dhomh fhìn into myself
dhut fhèin into yourself
dhi fhèin into herself/itself
dha fhèin into himself/itself
dhuinn fhìn into ourselves
dhuibh fhèin into yourselves
dhaibh fhèin into themselves

Some examples –
older pedagogical examples –
Tha mo mhàthair a’ sgrìobhadh litreach gu m’athair a tha air falbh. Thubhairt mo mhàthair, “An téid thu do bhocsa nan litrichean leis an litir seo, Iain?” “Théid,” ars Iain, “falbhaidh mi an dràsda”. “Fuirich gus an dùin mi i is gus an cuir mi seòladh oirre. Ceannaich fhéin stamp agus cuir oirre i.” Tha Iain a’ ruith sìos an rathad leis an litir ’na làimh. Théid e a steach do oifig a’ phuist, ceannaichidh e stamp is cuiridh e sud air an litir. [...]
My mother is writing a letter to my father who is away. My mother said, “Will you go to the postbox with this letter, John?” “Yes, I will,” said John, “I will leave now.” “Wait until I seal it and put an address on it. Buy a stamp and put it on it.” John is running down the road with the letter in his hand. He will go into the post office, he will buy a stamp and put that on the letter. [...] td. 5
biblical examples –
A Nis is iad so ainmeanna chloinn Israeil, a thàinig do’n Eiphit; thàinig gach duine agus a theaghlach maille re Iacob: Reuben, Simeon, Lebhi, agus Iudah, Isachar, Sebulun, agus Beniamin, Dan, agus Naphtali, Gad, agus Aser. [...]
Now these are the names of the children of Israel, which came into Egypt; every man and his household came with Jacob. Reuben, Simeon, Levi, and Judah, Issachar, Zebulun, and Benjamin, Dan, and Naphtali, Gad, and Asher. [...] [KJV] Ecsodus I.1–5

do can be used to introduce the complement of a verb –
rach do ... go [to] somewhere
thig do ... come [to] somewhere

Or of an adverb –
a-steach do ... into
